text: The gym is filled to the rafters with screaming students cheering on their basketball team. One particularly good looking player, who we’ll learn later is JOHN TUCKER, fak one way, spins in the other direction and dunks. The gym goes nuts. We push in on a girl, KATE (17), sitting in th stands. She’s high up and she’s there alone - she has a b in her hand which she reads during time outs. She’s prett but not made up too much, and she’s dressed comfortably, as not to draw too much attention to herself.
I was in seventh grade when I realized I was invisible.
A teacher arranges a group of seventh grade girls in line height. Kate is towards the middle.

Not really invisible - although, how awesome would that have been? No, it’s just that I didn’t make an impression of any kind. If I disappeared, it wouldn't even cause a ripple. A teacher shifts a young Kate one space over, now exactly middle.
I wasn’t the tallest or the shortest, I wasn’t the smartest or the dumbest, I wasn’t the richest or the poorest... I was just what’s-her-name, you know, the brunette? Kate, I think?
A spelling bee is in progress, as a young Kate takes her at the podium. She’s one of seven people left.
A-N-O-N-I-M-O-U-S. Anonymous.
I’m sorry, that’s wrong. Kate walks away.
It’s not that I didn’t try - I was a pretty good speller, and a pretty good singer, and a pretty good runner-
A group of girls run past the finish line.
And in fourth place, just out of the medals, Kate Spencer.
The auditorium is decorated for a dance and is filled wit freshman boys and girls. Freshman Kate sits against the wall, trying to look like a great person to dance with.

Even in love... well, I usually ended up out of medal contention there, too. A good looking boy walks over and takes in Kate and the o wallflowers. He looks to Kate’s left - at a rather unfortunate looking girl. He shudders, looks at Kate. Not bad. He smiles, starts over, when a hot girl to Kate’s ri suddenly pops into view - she’d been picking a button off floor.

Found it! She and the boy lock eyes - the boy veers off from Kate a holds out his hand to the hot girl. They twirl off like F and Ginger. INT. GIRL’S LOCKER ROOM - DAY Kate stands at a locker by herself, getting dressed, as o groups of girls around her talk.

It didn’t help that my mom and I were always moving. You can put up with just about anything when you’ve got a bunch of great friends to help you through, but, well, let’s just say “openness to outsiders” isn’t really what teens are famous for. One of the girls near Kate turns to her friends.
I don’t have anything for my hair. Do you have a barrette or something? Kate surreptitiously pulls the elastic band out of her ha turns to the girl. (CONTINUED)
Hey, I’ve got one.
Do I know you?
Not really...
Pass. The girls head out. The locker room is empty now; Kate’s alone. She sighs, puts her hair back together.
We're in the living room of a house on moving day - boxes furniture scattered everywhere. A sweaty Kate staggers through with a box.

There was one last thing working against me. There’s a knock at the door. She turns and drops the box when she sees who it is - it’s an older boy, a knockout. holds out a plate wrapped with aluminum foil.

(too cool) Hey. I’m Justin, I live next door, and my mom sent me over with these brownies or something... Kate takes the plate while she tries to push her hair int some arrangement that’s not too disgusting.
(flustered) Hi. I’m Kate. I just moved in. Duh.
So, Kate, you- Something catches Justin’s eye.

Holy... Kate turns to see what he’s looking at - a gorgeous woman her early thirties just walked into the room. She’s been working, too, but instead of sweating, she’s glistening l a Sports Illustrated swimsuit model on a beach in Fiji. (CONTINUED)
She’s dressed in shorts and a t-shirt that may have fit h in grade school.
That other thing working against me?
This is my Mom.
Lori. Hi. Justin takes the plate out of Kate’s hand and holds it ou Lori.
I made these for you. (then) I can pick up heavy things.
Kate sits at her desk, taking notes as she reads a textbo
It’s not like she can help it. She’s just incredibly beautiful and skimpily dressed. Okay, maybe she can help that part. Kate looks up from her book.

Did you get this on page fifty-one? Andy? We see that Kate is studying with a boy, but he’s looking the window. Down by the pool, Kate’s mother is tanning fa down, with her top on the pool deck beside her.
Turn over turn over turn over turn over turn over turn over...

It’s not like being beautiful has made her life any easier. I mean, she’s never had trouble landing great looking men, she’s just had trouble keeping them. In the last seventeen years, she’s been through four marriages and I don’t know how many boyfriends. That’s why we’re always moving.
A quick series of shots of different great looking men staring into the camera. (CONTINUED )
Hi
Kate
I'm
going
to
be
your
new
dad. Your mom and I are going to, uh, talk in the bedroom, so you be a good girl and watch TV. Actually, here’s twenty bucks. You mind running down to the store and getting me some smokes?
We're back at the game we started at, with Kate in the stands.
But enough about me. The real story here is John Tucker.

John, our star basketball player, has the ball again. He passes it - no, he’s kept in the palm of his hand, he dri and dumps off to a teammate who’s free under the basket f lay up. More cheers, high fives all around. John’s a stud tall, buff, best head of hair on campus.
That’s John Tucker. Captain of the basketball team, family’s loaded, always voted most likely to everything, lost his virginity at 14. To the french teacher. (CONTINUED)
A pretty woman in her twenties, wearing a French flag sweatshirt and waving a team flag, cheers John on.
John hassles the passer, then jogs backwards on defense.

He’s the guy this school revolves around. At least, he used to be until... You know what? I’m getting ahead of myself. It all started when my mom got divorced again, and we moved to this town to “start over.” I got a job as a waitress at what turned out to be John’s favorite restaurant. I wasn’t the best waitress ever, but I wasn’t the worst...

Kate comes out of the kitchen and crosses over to find Jo Tucker (in suit and tie) sitting at a table with CARRIE, editor of the school paper. Carrie’s a super-smart overachiever with roughly a thousand commitments taking u her time. She’s also (like everyone with John) very prett
Are you ready...?
(to Carrie) I’m not sure... Are you ready?
Do you recommend anything?
Me? What do you recommend? You're the one who speaks Italian.
I don't speak it, I know a little...

That you picked up travelling around Europe. You’re so lucky. I can only imagine walking around the same streets where all those artists and poets walked, looking at the same sights Shakespeare looked at when he wrote (gazing into Carrie’s eyes) “Her beauty makes this vault a feasting presence full of light...” (MORE ) (CONTINUED )
(then) Maybe I don’t need to go to Europe after all. Carrie blushes, gives a flustered laugh. John turns to Ka
I guess we need a minute. Thanks. Kate walks off - it’s clear she’s more than a little impressed by John’s display.

It's a different night at Kate’s restaurant. Kate comes o of the kitchen loaded down with plates. She hears a snapping, glances towards the source, then does a double take. John Tucker (in a letterman’s jacket) is there with different girl, HEATHER, who couldn’t look more like a cheerleader because she is a cheerleader. She’s been popu and beautiful for so long that she’s grown to believe tha her superiority is the natural order of things. John keep snapping at Kate without looking, finally Kate gets the plates down and heads over to John’s table.
Hi. Would you-
We’re ready to order.
Uh, okay. (to Heather) What would you like?
I’ll order for her. Heather puts down her menu, gets a huge smile on her face
I love that.
(all charm) I love taking care of you. (to Kate, all business) Two spinach salads, chicken piccata for her, filet for me, medium. And don’t rush us between courses. Got it?
Uh, yeah. Can I- But John’s done with her, and has turned back to Heather. (CONTINUED )
That sweater is so hot on you. I bet it’s even hotter off you. Heather laughs; Kate walks away shaking her head - what happened to the John that was here the other night?
Yet another night. John Tucker (in slacker-wear) sits at table with BETH. She’s a hippie throwback, a young Drew Barrymore type. She and John are looking at their menus.
I’ve never been here, I hope they have good vegetarian... (off the menu) Oh my Goddess.
What?
Veal. lLet’s go.
Don’t worry, I’m sure I can find something. ANGLE ON: Kate, standing over at a waitstation with anoth waitress. She’s gestures at John.
What's the deal with-
John Tucker. Total operator. Brings all his women here.
How does he get away with dating so many women?

(bitter laugh) He says his father doesn’t want him dating during the basketball season so he “keeps his focus.” Total lie. It’s just another one of his scams so they have to keep the “relationship” secret.
Unbelievable. How’d you learn all this? The waitress starts to cry and runs back into the kitchen

Kate is in gym class with the other girls, including John three current girlfriends (Heather, Carrie and Beth). They’re picking teams for volleyball - about half the gir are still waiting to be picked, including Kate. Heather ( cheerleader) is one of the girls picking. She points at Kate.
Uh... I’11 take her.
(too eager) Kate. Hi. I didn’t catch your name? Heather looks at Kate like she’s nuts.
Okay, moving on.
The game’s in progress. A point is scored, and while a gi runs after the ball to retrieve it, Carrie (the editor) i gossiping with the girl standing next to her.
You weren’t at the party. Where were you?
I’m not suppose to say, but... (quietly) John Tucker. Behind Carrie, Heather is getting ready to serve. She obviously heard this - her mouth drops wide open.
Get out! COACH WILLIAMS, the gym teacher, blows her whistle.
Less talking, more playing. Serve it. Heather tosses the ball in the air and serves it - right the back of Carrie’s head. Carrie is knocked on her face.
Sorry. It slipped. The girls around Carrie (including Kate) pick her up. (CONTINUED)

I’m okay, I’m okay. Let’s just play. Every gets back in position and Heather serves again - ri into the back of Carrie’s head, sending her down again. Carrie jumps up and runs over to Heather, as the other gi crowd around and the coach starts madly blowing her whist
That wasn’t an accident! Beth (the hippie) gets between Carrie and Heather, who ig her as they keep arguing.
You better stay away from him.
Violence isn’t going to solve anything.
What’s it to you?
No man is worth us fighting over.
Listen, I don’t know what he told you, but John Tucker is dating me. Now Beth’s mouth drops - she turns and slugs Heather in t jaw, dropping her to the floor.
(from the floor) What the hell is your problem?
I’m dating John Tucker. Coach Williams has finally made it over.

Enough. She grabs Carrie, who grabs the coach’s clipboard and swi it at Beth. Beth moves, and Kate gets hit instead. It’s a all out melee now, with Kate accidentally caught in the middle. People are falling, arms are swinging, and finall Kate snaps:
Stop it! This guy is cheating on all of you and instead of being mad at him, you’re beating the crap out of each other?! (CONTINUED )
ll.
Silence as the girls look at each other, digesting the wi of what Kate said. Finally, Beth turns to Heather:
Who’s that?
I don’t know. Pam, maybe? INT. GIRL’S BATHROOM - DAY Kate is at the mirror, trying to cover up the bruise on h cheek from where she got hit. Carrie comes in.
Hey.
Hey.
Sorry about your face. Kate, right?
Yeah. It only hurts when I smile. Or talk. Or do this. She makes a face in the mirror, winces. Carrie laughs.
What you said out there-
Sorry, someone just sat on me and-
Yeah, that was me. But the thing is, you were right.
I was?
Look what he’s doing to us girls. I don’t even know you, and I hit you in the head with a clipboard.
That was you too, huh? Anyway, I’ve seen a million John Tuckers, they all lie to get what they want, and the girls always put up with it. (CONTINUED)
You’re totally right. I never understood it until now, but you’re right.
Well, it helps that those are the only guys my mom dates. Pretty soon, you figure out they're all the same.
Come on. I’ve got some planning to do, and then we've got to talk to Beth and Heather.
We? You want me to come?
Sure, in case we start fighting again, I’ve got to have someone to hide behind.
What the heck. I think my head can absorb three or four more good shots before I have brain damage. Carrie heads out of the bathroom; Kate in tow.
Kate, Carrie, Beth and Heather sit at a table. Beth and Heather don’t look too happy to be there.
Be honest. What are you going to do about John?
I’m totally breaking up with him.
No you're not.
Like you are.
It’s up to him. If he dumps you two, I’1l take him back.
We’re going to end up right back where we started. He’ll get back together with all of us, lie about it until he decides he’s done with us and then dump us for good. (CONTINUED)
Beth and Heather stare at Carrie, unconvinced. Kate clear her throat.
I bet I know what you’re thinking. “I’m different. I’m the one he’s going to stay with forever.” Beth and Heather look at each other, look down.
Maybe.
Why not? I am the head cheerleader.
You say that like it makes you some kind of god and we’re all losers.
No. I mean, a little, but no. I don’t think that.
Let’s stay focused here. Everyone he’s ever dated thinks they’re different. It’s what he does.
So what are we supposed to do?
Kate had an idea.
I was just saying it’s always the women who end up getting hurt...
Exactly. Why is he getting off the hook? We could all date anyone, and for some reason we let him walk all over us.
It’s because he’s hot.
Hot? He’s the most gorgeous man I’ve ever seen. He’s like a Greek god, sent to earth to remind us mortals what beauty is. Beth notices everyone staring at her. She snaps out of it (CONTINUED)
But you’re right. That’s not enough.
So why not teach him a lesson?
How? Break up with him? He’1l have someone else in a second.
No, bigger. We're going to make him undateable, make it so no one wants to go out with him anymore. Carrie pulls out a huge sheath of color-coded papers and folders, hands a thick stack to each girl.

I had some time to go over some possible approaches. I’11 bottom line it: he doesn’t know we’re on to him. We can use the fact that we’re his “girlfriends” to set him up, humiliate him, and make him look like a fool in front of the whole school.
(smiles, imagining it) That wouldn’t suck.
And we won’t just be taking care of him. We'll be sending a message to all the John Tuckers that we’re not going to put up with it anymore. They’re going to have to treat us with respect.
They’re going to have to stop lying to us.
And cheating on us.
Exactly! I’ve got a whole section on that starting on page three.
(paging through thick folder) When do you sleep?
I take ten minute naps five times a day. I’m like Thomas Edison. (CONTINUED)
(whispers to Beth) Who?
(whispers back) He was a President.
Come on, what do you say? A beat, then:
Let’s get him.
I’m in. But if I find out this is some kind of trick, I’m back with him so fast... Carrie pulls out a small leather notebook, writes in it. Yes, this has some significance later.
Wow, this is great. He doesn’t stand a chance against you guys.
You’re not going to help us?
Me? Why me?
It was your idea.
No, I just pointed out that you all should do something. He didn’t do anything to me.
Didn't he? He got all of us mad enough to beat the crap out of you in gym.
Besides, can you honestly say that you haven’t been screwed over by a John Tucker somehow, somewhere?
Come on, it'll be fun. What else are you doing? Heather has a good point. Kate shrugs. (CONTINUED)
Let’s get him.

Different groups are using the track: the female track te (including Kate) is running sprints, and the cheerleaders led by Heather, are just finishing up practice as random people jog by on the track. One of them is John Tucker, w stops and waits for Heather to wander over and join him. glances around to make sure no one is within earshot.
Heard there was a thing in gym yesterday.
Some loser was saying she went out with you.
You're kidding. That’s such a lie.
Oh, I totally know. Don’t worry. I mean, you can’t date-
(sadly) The basketball.
But if you could, I know who it’d be.
You know it, babe. John looks around to makes sure no one’s watching, slaps Heather on the ass. ACROSS THE FIELD: Kate is standing at a drinking fountain watching.
Euch. There's a guy standing behind her at the fountain, SCOTT.
Is that for her or him?
Him. (CONTINUED)
That’s not usually the noise girls make when they look at him. Usually it’s more of a “ohhhhh...”
(laughs) Jerk isn’t really my type.
I guess he is kind of a jerk, isn’t he?
I’m surprised to hear a guy say that. I thought he was your god.
Close. Older brother.
Oh no. Seriously? Scott holds out his hand.
Scott Tucker.
Kate. I’m so embarrassed-

Don’t be. If anything, I’m embarrassed about being his brother. I think my mom was experimenting with drugs or living on a toxic waste dump when she had him. Kate laughs. They’re interrupted by a bell. SCOTT (CONT’D) Damn, I’ve got to run. Don’t worry, your secret’s safe with me, Kate. Scott winks and heads off. INT. KATE’S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - DAY Heather and Carrie are sitting in Kate’s living room as K opens the door and lets Beth in. Carrie has a new Apple Powerbook plugged into Kate’s television - on the screen Keynote presentation, complete with an unflattering pictu of John and a list of bullet points next to him. Very sli
Did you talk to him? (CONTINUED)
Heather
Yeah, he just stopped by my house. He said I’m the only one for him, you guys are liars, meat is murder...
Yeah, we all got the same story.
Your house? Did you hook up?
No.
Oh my god. You did.
No. A little. (then) We can’t let him get suspicious! I always fool around with him! It wasn’t for me, it was for us! I mean, I enjoyed it, but... It wasn’t for me! and Carrie exchange a look.
Told you she couldn't keep it together.
Figures you two would gang up on me. Little Miss Popular and Little Miss Perfect.
Hey, don’t lump me with her.
What’s that supposed to mean?
Just that we’re very different.
Meaning you're better than me. Kate laughs. Everyone looks at her.
Don’t you see? This is exactly how he gets away with it. He knows you wouldn't be caught dead talking to each other, and that’s why he’s so safe cheating. (CONTINUED)
Kate’s right. I’m sorry. We've got to stick together, all right? The girls nod. There's
Okay, he’s back with all of us, he doesn’t know anything's up, let’s keep it that way until we get him.
Speaking of which, does anyone have any idea how we’re going to do this? a pause. Heather holds up one of Carrie’s folders.
I mean, I read Carrie’s term paper-
No you didn’t.
Okay, but come on, it’s like the phone book. I flipped through, and didn’t see anything, um...
Concrete. Yeah. You’ve got some great ideas, but what do we do?

Well, I mean, I don’t know him like you all do, but I noticed something. He makes every woman he’s with feel special, he tells them exactly what they want to hear... what if we showed people that it’s just an act? Really show who he is, so no one ever trusts him again? I mean, when I saw him, I thought he was cute, but after I saw how he was with all of you... The girls take this in, nodding.
Excellent. Good. Throw those away. Carrie grabs all the folders.
Let’s get to work. (ve: computer) Beth, you mind starting the presentation? (CONTINUED)
Beth goes to the computer, reaches for a key.
Not that. Just press the- no, not that. Move the cursor to- You know what? I’11 work the computer. Carrie pushes Beth out of the way, cradles her computer.
I’m glad we're getting to know each other. I'd always heard you were kind of a control freak.
Kate, you get sodas.
Diet.
And Heather, you...
Sit here and look good until you need me?
Are we a well oiled team or what? Kate goes into the kitchen.
Kate enters just as her mother comes in from outside, carrying a bag of groceries. Lori’s dressed in her usual young, hip, sexy way, looking more like a teen than a mom
Hey, what’s up?
Oh, nothing, just- Laughter from the next room.
You have friends over?
Yeah, a few girls stopped by. Lori hugs Kate. (CONTINUED)
I knew you'd like it here. This is great. I can’t wait to meet them. Lori heads out of the kitchen.
Actually, we’re- Too late. Lori’s gone. Kate grabs sodas and follows. INT. KATE’S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - CONTINUOUS Kate enters the room right behind Lori.
Beth, Carrie, Heather, this is my mom.
Lori. The girls all exchange looks - Lori doesn’t look like a m
So what are you all up to?
Destroying a man.
Who do I make my check out to? The girls laugh. Lori crosses over and sits on the floor with the girls.
So, who is he and what did he do? Beth presses a key on her computer; John zooms back onto screen, along with ominous sound effect music and booing.
This is John Tucker.
Cute. Let me guess, heartbreaker?
Big time.
You’re lucky I got here. I’ve got some experience in this field. (CONTINUED)
Kate can’t take any more. She pastes on a smile, trying v hard not to let her true feelings out.
Mom, I really don’t know if we should be taking advice about men from you.
Why not? I’ve dated a hundred of them. I know all their tricks.
And yet, you still keep going falling for them.
What’s the matter? She’s an expert.

Okay, then. Kate shrugs, hands out the sodas, takes a seat. She’s not happy camper. Carrie takes her place at her computer - he talk is illustrated by an impressive presentation, comple with video, graphics, music, etc...

All right, Kate’s right. We need to show people the real John Tucker. And to do that, we need a public platform - something where the whole school is there. That much I’ve already got figured out. Ladies and... ladies, I give you: the school election.
(unimpressed) The election?
He’s not even running.
Yes, the election, and he will run. Beth, you’re going to convince him.
How do I do that?
How do girls get boys to do anything?  23.

The hall is empty. Suddenly, the door to the boys bathroo crashes open, and Beth and John stumble into the hallway, an embrace. They break; Beth tucks in her shirt, John wip the lipstick off his face. Beth pauses under a political poster - a slick one with a photo of a smiling guy runnin for school president.
You know, I’m surprised you never ran for any kind of office.
It’s just something you do to get into college, and I’ve got the basketball.

Yeah, I guess you’re right. Still, it’s a big popularity contest, and there’s no way he’s more popular than you. Beth heads back towards her class, leaving John looking u the poster. He doesn’t look happy.

Carrie sits at a computer in the middle of a chaotic pile photos, old issues, submissions... There’s one other stud working there - he looks up as John enters. Unseen to Carrie, John points at the door, and the student takes of
Hey, Carrie. What do you think about me running for school president?
I didn’t think you got into that.
I never did, and all of a sudden I realized I’m missing part of the high school experience.
It’s a little late to be getting involved-
I’ve got to win. You’ll help me. You're the smartest girl I know, you run the newspaper-
(pretending to soften) You want my help? Well... (CONTINUED )
I knew you’d do it. I love you.
What? John acts surprised, like he didn’t mean to let that slip out. He clearly did.
I mean, I love you for helping. I can’t believe I said that.
No, it’s okay... He holds her hand, gazes into her eyes, then:
So, you'll do it?
The four girls are sitting together at a table. Heather takes a bite of her burger, grimaces.
Since when do we eat here?
Since we can’t be seen together. If he hears we're friends, he’1l know something's up. Come on, it’s not that bad. Carrie samples her food, shudders, gingerly returns the b to her napkin.

Anyone have a napkin they’re not using so I can blot the grease off my tongue? Kate hands over a napkin. Carrie licks it. Beth begins doing surgery on her sandwich - the other girls’ watch as removes the meat patty from her burger, removes the chees replaces the tomato and lettuce, and squirts about a quar ketchup and mustard onto it. She takes a bite, notices th she’s being watched.
Being a vegetarian sucks. I want a personal thank you note from every stupid cow and chicken I haven’t eaten. (CONTINUED)
Okay, here’s where we are. I’ve already convinced John that we should show a video for his campaign speech.
A video that, let me guess, you'll be editing?
Isn’t he going to want to see it before you show it?
I’m going to make two. I make a real one to show him, where he talks about all the things that make him a good candidate - loyalty, honesty...
And we make another one where we cut ina bunch of stuff about what a sleazebag he really is.
Gee, I hope there’s not some mix-up, and we end up showing the wrong video to the whole school. It would ruin him. They laugh.
To get the footage we need, we’re going to need a lot of equipment - microphones, hidden cameras...
Beth, that’s you.
I don’t know anything about electronics.
Yeah, but you're rich.
Hey, I don’t like labels. My parents may buy into the whole bourgeois lifestyle, but that doesn’t mean I have to. It’s their money, not mine.
If we agree that you’re a poor repressed member of the underclass, can we use one of your fifty credit cards? (CONTINUED)

Sure. Beth digs through her purse, pulls out credit cards, hand one to each girl. BETH (CONT’D) AmEx Blue, Visa Platinum... (sentimental) Oh, my first Master Card. We’ve had some fun, haven’t we? She reluctantly hands it over.

Be careful with him. His little magnetic strip’s almost worn off. INT. HEATHER’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Heather’s bedroom is covered with bags from electronics stores and spy stores. Beth and Carrie are playing with monitors, binoculars, etc. Heather’s in just a bra, as Ka tries to attach a camera with fumbling hands.
All right, almost there. Sorry, I’ve never done this.
Put a camera on someone, or groped a girl?
Well, neither. Kate gets the camera on.
There, how does that feel?
Well, the camera kind of pinches, but you've got soft hands. Beth turns on a monitor - we see a huge distorted close u Kate’s face as shot through the camera.
Whoa.
How do I look? (CONTINUED)
Tres bad angle - straight up your nose. Take two steps back from Heather’s breasts. Kate does. BETH (CONT’D) Much better. The lighting still isn’t great. Try turning to the left.
Oh, we're not doing this to get glamor shots of Kate. Kate, speak into the cleavage. Carrie puts on a pair of headphones as Kate steps back up Heather.
Um, testing. One two. Testing.
Okay, it’s good. There’s kind of an echo, but it’s good.
What do I want him to say?
Well, we want him to act like a sleazy horndog, so...
Just let him be himself?
That’11 work. Carrie pulls out her notebook, starts writing.
Sorry, do you mind if I ask... what are you always writing in there?

Just my lists. You know, normal stuff, same aS everyone. (off their blank looks) I've got my “to do” list, which is subdivided into my “to do today,” “to do one time,” “to do weekly,” you know. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

Then there's my “goals” list, again, “high school,” “college,” and “life;” my “contingency” lists in case one of my goals or to do items doesn’t work out the way I expected, my “observations,” my “notions,” which yes, are very different, and of course a few ideas for the screenplay I plan to write during my summer in Belize. Or Toronto, depending on the political climate. Don’t you all do this?
No. No one does that. Martha Stewart would meet you and go “you know, she’s a little anal for my taste.”
Well, it works for me.
What happens if you lose the book?
You’re not going to freak me out that easily. I have a duplicate at home, and I copy the changes in every night.
Yeah, but what about all the “contingencies” and “notions” you come up with during the day? They’d just be... gone forever? Carrie processes this. Her eyebrow twitches. The girls go in for the kill.
Yeah, maybe you should carry a third book-
Stored in a separate location from the main book, of course-

Kissing you? Romantically? Although every second we talk about it, it’s becoming less romantic and more uncomfortable. You’re just looking at me. Time is passing. It’s getting really bad now.
And just exactly long have you been attracted to me? (CONTINUED)
I think I suspected it when I first saw you, and I was sure when you glued your tongue to your mouth...
So why didn’t you say anything? You know, this is all kind of your fault. You should have asked me out the second you met me, not taken “no” for an answer, and saved me from this whole mess.
I’m... sorry?

Amazingly, another John Tucker didn’t spring up to take his place. From that time on, the guys at our school treated the women like princesses.
